Award.AwardTitle: 13th Solanaceae Conference, SolGenomics: Advances and Applications, Davis, California, September 12-16, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Solanaceous crops include tomato, bell pepper and potato, among others, and together these crops represent a significant part of the agricultural production in the United States. This workshop/conference has targeted participants from academia, government and industry to bring to them the latest scientific developments that impact on the improvement of these crops and their productivity. The organizers aim to recruit faculty, professionals, postdoctoral associates and students from diverse institutions, and are particularly targeting students and postdocs from underrepresented groups. In addition to scientific sessions, the program includes sessions dedicated to career development for students and postdocs looking for a future in academia, industry or government.

Unlike previous Solanaceae Conferences that addressed crop specific topics, this conference will focus on a range of topics that are applicable and relevant to all crops in this group. Topics included in this conference include genomics encompassing different genotypic technologies that can be used for taxonomic and assisted breeding purposes, epigenetics and characterization of the methylome. Other sessions include high-throughput phenotyping, and physiological and developmental studies of different organs that impact productivity, resistance to pathogens, and the analysis of metabolites that affect the nutrition and flavor characteristics of these commodities. Workshops included cover career development, pathogen strain identification, and the use or web resources like the Solanacea Genomics Network and iPlant/CyVerse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview
The 13th Solanaceae Conference, SolGenomics: Advances and Applications was held in Davis, California on September 12-16, 2016. The Conference web site is: http://solgenomics2016.ucdavis.edu/.  

Intellectual merit
The intellectual merit of the conference is communication of research advances in Solanaceous crop and wild species and experiential learning for graduate students and postdocs for presentation and professional skills, as well as career opportunities. The target audience include: faculty, scientists, students, postdocs and managers in private and public interested in the latest research, translational and applications of technologies in improving Solanaceous crops and species. The particular emphasis of the 13th Annual meeting was to highlight advances from genomics to applications for crops and other species. Rather than focusing on crop-specific topics as in the past, the conference focused on fourteen disciplines and technology areas including:

Diversity-taxonomy/Crop germplasm diversity   Abiotic Stresses

Barriers to Breeding                                             Resistance, Pathology, Pests and Microbiomes

Genomes and Genome Technologies                    Tubers and Root Systems

Gene Editing and New Breeding Technologies    Flowers, Seeds and Fruit

Epigenomics and Methylation                              Plant Development and Regulation

Genomic-assisted Breeding                                  Metabolites, Flavor and Quality

High-throughput Phenotyping                              Systems Biology and Networks

Additionally tours on research and commercial-scale farms and facilities were offered at UC Davis Tomato Genetics Resource Center, Pepper breeding program including Capsicum diversity garden (NSF funded, Lyn Bohs grant# 1457351), HM Clause and Monsanto seed companies, Organic farming of solanaceous crops, Morningstar tomato processing and mechanical harvesting of tomato harvesting.The program held four well-attended workshops on career planning for students, database and software including Cyverse (NSF funded) and Solanaceae Genomics Network, and the Collaboration for Plant Pathogen Identification.  This conference brought together international researchers working on Solanaceae in genomics and plant breeding for first time. There were 363 particpants from 32 countries and 6 continents. 

Broader Impacts

The funding from NSF enabled participation by 12 under-represented and diverse students, covered costs of 14 student/postdoc speakers in the oral sessions, and allowed reduced registration costs for 136 (1/3 of participants) postdocs and graduate students.  This enabled students and postdoc participation with established researchers in an educational panel on careers.  Students were solicited from non-traditional colleges and universities. To further enrich the experiences of students/postdocs 40 students/postdocs had the opportunity for a 1-minute-personal and poster introduction.  This worked extremely well  to increase interactions during posters and providing exposure and experience for more speakers. A career workshop hosting a panel of four women, young researchers, farmers and plant breeders in public and industry was hosted. The 12 underrepresented studentswere selected to co-chair each of the sessions allowed them to be integrated into the program, learning the subject and meeting peers in the field. Outcomes were disseminated with abstracts on line, professional video interviews of the speakers and students and a Conference summary in Seedworld magazine (seedworld.com) and journal. Session summaries were also compiled by co-chairs and avaliable at the meeting website as well as the twitter site #solgenomics2016.
